subject: Different kinds of failure
msgSnippet: ... I like the idea of distinguishing between these kinds of failures: * an assertion failed * the test threw an unexpected exception * setUp() threw an
messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>
> > What is a partial failure?
>
> Your setUp() method fails halfway, so only half of the resources need to be
> freed.
>
> > The set up belongs to the test. I think it is reasonable to
> > say the test fails if its setup fails.
>
> No, it's not the tests that are failing, it's the setUp.
>
> Imagine you have 100 tests and 1 set up. The setUp fails, and now JUnit is
> telling you you have "101 FAILURES"... Very helpful! And QA will freak out
> on you. And I'm sure you already know you can't "trust" this report and
> that you are actually looking at a cascade failure.
>
> Compare this to "1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS".
>
> Now, *that* is a much more acurate view of what really happened.

I like the idea of distinguishing between these kinds of failures:

* an assertion failed
* the test threw an unexpected exception
* setUp() threw an unexpected exception

As for "skipping" tests, I reserve judgment until after I've tried it,
but I do like idea of distinguishing all those kinds of failures. This
would help people testing legacy code or writing larger tests. For TDD
work, though, it's mostly needless. If, all of a sudden, 20 tests
explode, I just hit UNDO a few times and try again, anyway. Soon, I'll
be able to "Return to Green Bar" in Eclipse. (Well, if not /soon/, then
/someday/.)
